terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Nevada desert. Moderate elevation with desert scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Local Nevada event. Desert terrain with remote access, low costs, and small local field.

biased_opinion.summary: Beaver Dam Gravel Grinder is a local event in Nevada—desert terrain with moderate elevation. The Nevada desert is scenic, but the very small field, remote location, and limited organization keep it in Tier 4.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid local Nevada desert gravel race. Worth it for Nevada/Southwest riders. Not worth traveling for.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're local to Nevada—yes, it's good value. If you're traveling—skip it.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better Nevada races: Ruby Roubaix, Gravel Worlds.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Beaver Dam has very limited lodging options. Plan ahead.
logistics.food: Beaver Dam has very limited dining options. Stock nutrition.
logistics.official_site: Check Beaver Dam Gravel Grinder website
logistics.camping: camping at Beaver Dam State Park

non_negotiables.why: Limited organization and remote location require self-sufficiency.

logistics.explanation: Camping at Beaver Dam State Park handles lodging, but organizer Dawn Andone warns 'the closest town is 35 miles down a gravel road.' Registration is open with 6:30-7:00 AM start times, though packet pickup details remain unspecified. As Dawn Andone (Organizer) puts it: "Stay at the Park! Come camp in one of two campgrounds at the park. The ride starts at 7:30 am and the closest town is 35 miles down a gravel road. Camping is your best option."

length.explanation: Dawn Andone notes 'riders usually complete the course in six hours' for the 50-mile distance. Multiple options exist (10, 35, and 45 miles), but the featured distance hits that recreational middle ground between quick ride and epic challenge. More compact than Grinduro.

technicality.explanation: Coach Mark Orton describes surfaces that 'vary from hard-packed dirt to softball-sized rocks.' Dawn Andone explains 'some rocky patches can be considered technical, but we have tried to keep those to a minimum.' Less technical than The Mid South. As Dawn Andone (Organizer) puts it: "Fat tire, gravel or mountain bikes all work well. Some areas can be rocky and others sandy."

elevation.explanation: Course travels 'along the rim of the park so you can see all the geologic formations' at approximately 5,000 feet elevation. The 3,000 feet of gain over 50 miles creates rolling terrain through pines and junipers rather than dramatic climbs. Less climbing than The Mid South.

climate.explanation: 2021 temperatures reached 106°F during the event, while 33 riders 'battled the wind' in 2022. June racing in Nevada desert demands early 6:30 AM starts, but heat management remains a significant challenge. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: The course runs at approximately 5,000 feet elevation through Beaver Dam State Park. High enough to affect sea-level riders but not Colorado-severe, sitting in that middle altitude range where fitness matters more than acclimatization. Modest altitude compared to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

adventure.explanation: Nevada's remote desert terrain and state park camping setting delivers adventure factor. Being the state's only gravel race adds pioneer appeal for Nevada cycling bragging rights. Remote location and sparse details suggest you're signing up for uncertainty, which some riders crave.

prestige.explanation: This is 'Nevada's 1st and only Gravel Grinder Event' which sounds impressive until you realize Nevada has like twelve people who ride gravel. Zero mention of notable winners, pros, or media coverage in the search results. Being first in Nevada is like being the tallest midget.

race_quality.explanation: The research turns up almost nothing about course details, aid stations, or organization quality. Official website exists and they have dates locked for 2025-2026, but that's bare minimum. When a race's own website doesn't showcase course maps or rider testimonials, that tells you everything. As Dawn Andone (Organizer) puts it: "The course is mostly over dirt and gravel backcountry and jeep roads. There are some rocky patches that can be considered technical, but we have tried to keep those to a minimum."

experience.explanation: No details on post-race festivities, awards, or memorable course features. You're buying a lottery ticket on whether this delivers anything beyond 'I rode 50 miles in Nevada.'

community.explanation: First-come-first-serve camping suggests grassroots vibes, but complete absence of rider forums, race reports, or community buzz is telling. When gravel nerds aren't talking about your race online, either it's brand new or forgettable. Nevada's small cycling scene limits growth potential.

field_depth.explanation: Field of 33 riders in 2022 with six-hour average completion times suggests recreational participation levels. Non-timed format and emphasis on friendship over competition attracts weekend warriors rather than competitive depth. Thinner field than Ouray Gravel Grinder.

value.explanation: $60 registration includes park entry, breakfast, lunch, and dinner according to research. State park camping keeps lodging costs low, and the meal package plus aid station support delivers solid value for a non-competitive event. As Dawn Andone (Organizer) puts it: "This is a fun time! Nevada State Parks strives to make your trip and the event one you will remember for a lifetime. We have a number of riders who return every year."

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $50-75. Nevada location means flight costs for most riders, but Beaver Dam State Park camping keeps lodging cheap. No nearby major airports mentioned in research, suggesting drive time from Vegas or Salt Lake. Remote location cuts both ways on expense. Higher total cost than Badlands.

key_takeaways: Lodging options and strategy: Official site mentions camping at Beaver Dam State Park; "State Parks is now on a camping reservation system; if you did

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: Panaracer GravelKing SK
primary.why: Affordable all-rounder. Light knobs add grip without killing speed.

primary.name: Vittoria Terreno Mix
primary.why: Graphene versatility. Mixed-terrain grip with reasonable rolling speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners
